conclusion: Problem involves finding heat transferred for an ideal gas changing states.
Gas changes from state A to B to C on a p-V diagram.
State A: pressure is 3 × 10^5 Pa, volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
State B: pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa, volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
State C: pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa, volume is 3 × 10^-3 m³.
Temperature at state A is 27°C, which is 300 K.
Use ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
Plan to find heat transferred from A to B to C.
From A to B, volume is constant, pressure decreases.
No work is done from A to B since volume is constant.
Internal energy change (ΔU) depends on temperature change.
Need temperature at state B to find ΔT.
Calculate T_B using ideal gas law: T_B = (P_B / P_A) * T_A.
ΔU is negative, internal energy decreases.
Q = ΔU = nCv(-200 K).
Calculate n using state A data: n = (P_A V_A) / (R T_A).
n ≈ 0.1202 moles.
For monatomic gas, Cv = (3/2) R.
Uncertainty if gas is monatomic or diatomic.
Keep Q_AtoB in terms of Cv: Q_AtoB = -200 n Cv J.
